quote: Our government is committed to righting past wrongs and addressing ongoing challenges.
It is our shared hope that we can learn from this past and continue to advance our journey of reconciliation and healing.
It is essential to recognize that Canada’s relationship with its Indigenous peoples has not been easy.
We have to understand the reasons that led us here.
In partnership with Indigenous peoples, we have taken important first steps.
We must do more to ensure that Canada’s prosperity is shared by Canada’s Indigenous people.
In the journey of reconciliation you no longer have to walk alone.
We understand that the status quo is not sustainable.
There is no question that Indigenous peoples have suffered injustices throughout Canada’s history.
As Canadians, we must confront our mistakes, learn from them, and work to right past and current wrongs.
There have been many conversations about the sad reality that Indigenous people are still subject to racism, both systemic and overt.
Our government has resolved to strengthen relationships with Indigenous governments and organizations.
We are at a pivotal moment in Canadian history and one of the first things we must all do is take a closer look at our past.
It is increasingly necessary that all Canadians learn about and understand the true history of Indigenous Peoples in our country.
These harms are a daily, lived reality for Indigenous peoples.
This is not something that happened in the past.
This is not something of the past but rooted in the present day.
We’ll continue to work in partnership with Indigenous peoples to advance this healing.
It will be a positive step in forging a new relationship between Indigenous peoples and other Canadians.
It is a shared journey we are on together.
There is painful but necessary work ahead and we must confront what happened for reconciliation to be achieved.
What we can offer is the solemn assurance that government policies have changed.
We are committed to ensuring this relationship grows deeper and stronger.
Only together, can we begin to heal the traumas of the past.
Walking this journey together, we will not fail.
Let’s work together for better social and economic equality, and fight against discrimination.
Through mutual respect, listening, and learning, we are making progress.
We still have much work ahead of us.
As government, we will work to deconstruct the colonial systems that are still in place and continue to harm Indigenous peoples.
We owe this to the future generations.
We should also strive to improve our understanding of the histories and cultures of Indigenous peoples.
Reconciliation is a journey we must take together.
Together, we can advance reconciliation and support Indigenous self-determination.
Reconciliation is collective accountability for all Canadians and requires action not just today, but every day.
We all have a role to play in reconciliation.
